column12: but then you get a flat tire

column56: and so did their parents. My parents made immense sacrifices to set us up for financial success

column59: and because I know I wonâ€™t get fired if I need to take extended absences due to my health.Â  So

column7: scary names are part of nature. An apple is full of compounds you probably canâ€™t pronounce. A shorter ingredients label only means they didnâ€™t bother listing all 300 things the product is actually made of and HAS to be made of. Preservatives

column2: years behind straight people in terms of dating. Because we are often closested and/or fearful for our safety and/or not around other gay people
column3: we donâ€™t get to hit all these â€œnormalâ€ dating milestones like expressing attraction to our crush and going through the awkward â€œfiguring things outâ€ stage or even learning how to get through a breakup. I donâ€™t even think we just postpone this process but because a lot of gay people are forced to pretend weâ€™re straight
column4: either by dating people as a beard or actually trying to force that attraction to be there
column5: we actually go backwards in the process so that when we finally are able to start dating for real
column6: we have to unlearn toxic internalized homophobia and heteronormativity in what becomes its own process
column7: usually lasting our whole lives.  We go through the world craving someone who understands our struggles and can relate to our experiences
column8: but when do we learn what our relationship is supposed to look like? When do we learn that our relationships maybe wonâ€™t look exactly like a straight personâ€™s
column9: that we have to regulate our fear of homophobia with our desire to hold our partners hand
column10: when do we learn that our sex isnâ€™t a fetish and our relationship wonâ€™t end in a â€œbury your gaysâ€ trope? We get stereotyped and mocked for moving in with our partner after only knowing them for two months
column11: for meeting our dates on Tinder/Grindr as if thereâ€™s some magical hub of gay people elsewhere that we just havenâ€™t found. But how else do we figure things out at 25 or or 45 or 75? Gay dating is such a different process from anything else we see day-to-day
column12: straight people donâ€™t realize this and sometimes we donâ€™t even realize it ourselves but itâ€™s true and even if you donâ€™t have all the answers understand that thatâ€™s expected and itâ€™s okay.   " False text

alexalfurinn 160138430850 "2017-04-30 02:50:31 GMT" https://alexalfurinn.tumblr.com/post/160138430850/discovery-may-help-decipher-ancient-inca-string "tlatollotl:  A discovery made in a remote mountain village high in the Peruvian Andes suggests that the ancient Inca used accounting devices made of knotted
column2: colored strings for more than accounting. The devices
column4: used combinations of knots to represent numbers and were used to inventory stores of corn
column6: and other provisions. Spanish accounts from colonial times claim that Inca khipus also encoded history
column9: but researchers have yet to decipher any non-numerical meaning in the chords and knots. Now a pair of khipus protected by Andean elders since colonial times may offer fresh clues for understanding how more elaborate versions of the devices could have stored and relayed information. Anthropologist Sabine Hyland studies a khipu board
column10: a colonial-era invention that incorporated earlier Inca technology. â€œWhat we found is a series of complex color combinations between the chords
column12: professor of anthropology at St. Andrews University in Scotland and a National Geographic Explorer. â€œThe chords have 14 different colors that allow for 95 unique chord patterns. That number is within the range of symbols in logosyllabic writing systems.â€ Hyland theorizes that specific combinations of colored strings and knots may have represented syllables or words. Her analysis of the khipus appears in the journal Current Anthropology. SECRET MESSAGES Hyland made her discovery in the Andean village of San Juan de Collata when village elders invited her to study two khipus the community has carefully preserved for generations. Village leaders said the khipus were â€œnarrative epistles about warfare created by local chiefs
column13: â€ Hyland reports. The khipus were stored in a wooden box that until recently was kept secret from outsiders. In addition to the khipus
column14: the box contained dozens of letters dating to the 17th and 18th centuries. Most of the documents are official correspondence between village leaders and the Spanish colonial government concerning land rights. Spanish chroniclers noted that Inca runners carried khipus as letters
column15: and evidence suggests that the Inca composed khipu letters to ensure secrecy during rebellions against the Spanish
column16: according to Hyland. A khipu from the Andean village of San Juan de Collata may contain information about the villageâ€™s history. â€œThe Collata khipus are the first khipus ever reliably identified as narrative epistles by the descendants of their creators
column17: â€ Hyland writes in her analysis. She notes that they are larger and more complex than typical accounting versions
column20: the Collata khipus were made from the hair and fibers of Andean animals
column26: and the rodent vizcacha. Animal fibers accept and retain dyes better than cotton
column27: and so they provided a more suitable medium for khipus that used color as well as knots to store and convey information. In fact several variablesâ€”including color
column29: even the direction of the chordsâ€™ weave or plyâ€”encode information
column31: so that reading the khipus requires touch as well as sight. Hyland cites a Spanish chronicler who claimed that khupus made from animal fiber â€œexhibited a diversity of vivid colors and could record historical narratives with the same ease as European books.â€ THE BIG QUESTION The Collata khipus are believed to date from the mid-18th century
column32: more than 200 years after Spanish colonizers first arrived in 1532. This raises the question whether they are a relatively recent innovation
column33: spurred on by contact with alphabetic writing
column34: or whether they bear a close similarity to earlier narrative khipus. â€œThese findings are historically very interesting
column35: but time is a big problem
column36: â€ says Harvard anthropologist Gary Urton. â€œWhether or not we can take these findings and project them into the past
column37: that remains the big question.â€ A few years ago
column38: Urton and Peruvian archaeologist Alejandro Chudiscovered a trove of khipus in what may have been a khipu workshop or possibly a repository of Inca records. [VIDEO AT NAT GEO WEBSITE] Deciphering patterns hidden within the devices may eventually become the work of computers
column39: Urton says. He and his Harvard colleagues maintain a digital repository called the Khipu Database that categorizes images
column41: and comparisons of more than 500 of the artifacts. The Inca at their height may have made thousands of khipus
column42: perhaps even hundreds of thousands. But archaeologists suspect that natural deterioration and European colonizers destroyed most of the devices. Fewer than 1
column43: 000 are known to exist today. Hyland plans to return to Peru in July to resume her research. Last summer
column44: on her last day of fieldwork
column45: she met an elderly woman who said she remembered using khipus as a young girl. But before Hyland could ask more questions
column46: the woman darted away to tend to her livestock. Hylandâ€™s goal is not only to solve a historical mystery
column48: but also to bring to light the â€œincredible intellectual accomplishments of Native American people.â€ " False link

alexalfurinn 158493393675 "2017-03-17 00:53:28 GMT" https://alexalfurinn.tumblr.com/post/158493393675/why-too-much-evidence-can-be-a-bad-thing "rykemasters: agnellina:  janothar:  jewish-privilege:  janothar:  arothejew:  jewish-privilege:  jewishzevran:  theunitofcaring:  Under ancient Jewish law
column2: if a suspect on trial was unanimously found guilty by all judges
column3: then the suspect was acquitted. This reasoning sounds counterintuitive
column4: but the legislators of the time had noticed that unanimous agreement often indicates the presence of systemic error in the judicial process
column5: even if the exact nature of the error is yet to be discovered. They intuitively reasoned that when something seems too good to be true
column6: most likely a mistake was made. In a new paper to be published in The Proceedings of The Royal Society A
column10: from Australia and France has further investigated this idea
column11: which they call the â€œparadox of unanimity.â€ â€¦ The researchers demonstrated the paradox in the case of a modern-day police line-up
column12: in which witnesses try to identify the suspect out of a line-up of several people. The researchers showed that
column13: as the group of unanimously agreeing witnesses increases
column14: the chance of them being correct decreases until it is no better than a random guess. In police line-ups
column15: the systemic error may be any kind of bias
column16: such as how the line-up is presented to the witnesses or a personal bias held by the witnesses themselves. Importantly
column17: the researchers showed that even a tiny bit of bias can have a very large impact on the results overall. Specifically
column18: they show that when only 1% of the line-ups exhibit a bias toward a particular suspect
column19: the probability that the witnesses are correct begins to decrease after only three unanimous identifications. Counterintuitively
column20: if one of the many witnesses were to identify a different suspect
column21: then the probability that the other witnesses were correct would substantially increase.  soâ€¦jews argue so much thereâ€™s something WRONG if we agree?  When someoneâ€™s life or liberty is on the line
column24: that is exactly the logic behind this
column25: and thatâ€™s itâ€™s better to err on the side of caution rather than condemn an innocent.    You may find this interesting - in any death penalty case (which Iâ€™ve explained elsewhere how difficult it is to get the death penalty) there was a panel of 23 judges. The Talmud in Tractate Sanhedrin explains that these 23 are divided into 3 groups. A group of 10 whose responsibility was to find legal loopholes or clear evidence
column27: in order to try and prove the defendant innocent
column28: a group of 10 who would argue against the defendant
column30: and a group of 3 to make the judgement and decide the ruling. The GOAL was to avoid the death penalty - at almost all costs - and to MAKE argument
column32: when there is argument and debate
column33: we are always more likely to come to the truth.  I saw this
column34: and almost posted it.Â  The paper is basically an academic paper saying â€œYeah
column35: that thing Jews have been doing for 3000 years? They nailed it.Â  If we all agree on something
column36: or if all our data is the same massive pile
column38: maybe thereâ€™s something wrong with our detectors
column39: thereâ€™s too much noise in reality for all our actual measurements to agree.â€  Share?  Here it is! That rare thing: a statistics paper that cites the Babylonian Talmud.  Yay! Thank you!  this is a great example of the value of historical comparison in social research tbh " False link

column1: alexalfurinn 158416544605 "2017-03-15 01:33:59 GMT" https://alexalfurinn.tumblr.com/post/158416544605/how-do-you-say-email-in-yiddish "witchy-woman:  jewish-privilege:   In a thousand-year-old language like Yiddish

column4: when it was the lingua franca of the Jews of Eastern Europe and the garment workers of the Lower East Side and was the chosen literary tongue for writers like Sholem Aleichem and Isaac Bashevis Singer. Though the Holocaust and assimilation have shrunk the ranks of Yiddish speakers â€” once put at over 11 million worldwide â€” to a relative handful
column5: Yiddish still needs to keep itself fashionably up-to-date. So two of its conservationists have produced the first full-fledged English-to-Yiddish dictionary in 50 years and it is designed to carry Yiddish into the 21st century and just maybe beyond. After all
column6: Yiddish has always had a canny way of defying the pessimists. â€œEmailâ€? How is â€œblitspostâ€ â€” a combination of the Yiddish words for â€œlightningâ€ and â€œmailâ€? â€œTransgenderâ€? Howâ€™s â€œtsvishnminik
column7: â€ which blends the common Yiddish words for â€œbetweenâ€ and â€œtype.â€ â€œDesignated driverâ€? â€œDer nikhterer shoferâ€ does the trick by fusing the Yiddish word for â€œsoberâ€ with that for â€œdriver.â€ And â€œbinge watchâ€ is â€œshlingen epizodn
